Award.AwardTitle: Finite Element Methods for Nonstationary Magnetohydrodynamics
Award.AbstractNarration:
The word magnetohydrodynamics derives from magneto-, meaning magnetic field, hydro-, meaning water, and dynamics, meaning movement. It describes the interaction of electrically-conducting fluids and electromagnetic fields. The fundamental concept behind magnetohydrodynamics (MHD) is that magnetic fields can induce currents in a moving conductive fluid, which in turn polarizes the fluid and reciprocally changes the magnetic field itself. Examples of such fluids include plasmas, liquid metals, and salt water or electrolytes. Applications of MHD play a role in many disciplines such as astrophysics, engineering related to liquid metal, and controlled thermonuclear fusion. Due to its significant role in applications, there have been many studies on the MHD systems from both theoretical and practical viewpoints. Designing and analyzing numerical methods to solve this system is in general a challenging task due to the multi-physical nature of the problem. The aim of this project is to develop novel numerical methods for solving MHD systems efficiently and accurately. The project provides opportunities for graduate and undergraduate student involvement in the research.

The governing equations of the MHD model display a nonlinear coupling between the nonstationary Navier-Stokes equations of fluid dynamics and Maxwell's equations of electromagnetism. With conventional numerical methods, the approximation may converge to a "wrong'' solution when the exact solution has singularities. In addition, for incompressible MHD models, both the velocity and magnetic fields are divergence free, and numerical computations that do not automatically preserve this property can suffer severe errors. This research aims to design robust structure-preserving numerical methods for MHD equations with high order convergent approximations for both smooth and nonsmooth domains. To achieve this goal, the project employs hybridizable discontinuous Galerkin methods (HDG) in view of their high order accuracy, easy implementation, flexible meshing, and local structure preserving for physical moments, etc. Because many applications require repeated simulations to obtain enough statistical data, this research project will also develop state-of-the-art ensemble HDG algorithms and will combine HDG schemes with other model reduction techniques to further enhance efficiency for large scale computations.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Magnetohydrodynamics (MHD) is the study of electrically conducting fluids in electromagnetic fields, with applications in areas such as plasma confinement for controlled thermonuclear fusion, liquid metal cooling of nuclear reactors, electromagnetic casting of metals, and flow measurement based on induction. The governing equations of the MHD model involve a nonlinear coupling between the time-dependent Navier-Stokes equations of fluid dynamics and Maxwell's equations of electromagnetism. Many practical MHD problems involve nonsmooth or nonconvex domains with reentrant corners, which can lead to singularities near those corners. Conventional numerical methods may fail to accurately approximate solutions in such cases, often converging to incorrect results when the exact solution exhibits singularities. Additionally, for incompressible MHD models, both the velocity and magnetic fields must remain divergence-free; failure to preserve this property during computation can lead to significant errors. Therefore, it is crucial to develop robust, structure-preserving numerical methods that can deliver accurate approximations in both smooth and nonsmooth domains. Furthermore, many applications require repeated simulations with different input parameters, necessitating efficient numerical methods capable of handling large-scale computations.

In this project, we analyze a numerical algorithm based on finite element methods for solving time-dependent MHD equations. Our analysis demonstrates that the algorithm preserves the divergence-free property of the magnetic field exactly at each time step. We also show that the linearized scheme is unconditionally stable and achieves optimal convergence.

Given the large-scale computations often required for simulating complex physical models such as MHD, we establish a framework to apply the proposed algorithm to various partial differential equations (PDEs) on multiscale meshes. We test the algorithm on 2D Darcy flow with a heterogeneous permeability field, and the numerical results are consistent with theoretical predictions. However, we find that the computational cost is primarily dominated by the so-called local solvers. To address this, we incorporate a neural network approach to train the local solvers for different local permeability fields, allowing the network to generate a Dirichlet-to-Neumann mapping rather than solving local fine-scale problems. Preliminary results show that this approach reduces overall computation time by a factor of 5 to 10 compared to the original multiscale HDG methods.
